settings.text: Chinti & Parker is delighted to celebrate its 10-year anniversary with a limited-edition collection of knitted Lurex eveningwear, all made in London. Here, our founders, Anna and Rachael, share ten of their brand-defining moments from the last decade.

settings.grid-content: Anna: “It was 2009, I’d just sold my beauty business, Pout, and Rachael had left Browns, so we found ourselves in a position to be able to set something up together. We get on very well and have similar tastes, so it felt like a natural step. At the time, we believed there was a gap in the market for a luxury jersey label with a European sensibility – classics with a twist; more stripes, more fun, more colours. As there wasn’t a lot of cashmere available at the time, we thought we’d add in some luxury sweaters for layering, too.”

settings.title: 2. A window to the world of fashion
settings.text: Rachael: “In 2011, Natalie Massenet had this idea to create a ‘green edit’ on Net-a-Porter and that’s how we first got onto the site, because we fit the criteria. All our jersey products were 100% organic, lots of our knitwear was made in London. I think in a week we sold through 85% of the collection.”

settings.grid-content:
Anna: “We worked on a sweater collaboration with Gwyneth Paltrow for Goop when they were still quite new. This was an exciting moment for Chinti as a brand, we were very flattered that we’d been asked to collaborate.”

Rachael: “Anna was invited to go over and meet Gwyneth in her London studio. I was on holiday, so I was really annoyed that I didn’t get to meet her. What was amazing is that she was really supportive of the brand before we collaborated. A couple of years after we worked together, she invited us to an intimate celebration for Goop’s birthday. I lucked out as I was on a table with all the really famous celebrities and had the best time ever.”

Rachael: “I love celebrities so for me I think it’s the most exciting thing ever when I see someone famous in Chinti & Parker. Malia Obama wearing one of our sweaters, holding her dad’s hand while they walked out of Air Force One together was a big moment.”

Anna: “Another highlight was Julia Roberts posting her first ever photograph to Instagram wearing Chinti. Other fashionable fans of the brand include Katie Holmes, Diane Kruger and Olivia Palermo.”

settings.title: 5. Chinti and Colette
settings.text: Anna: “Back in 2012 we worked on a collaboration with Parisian concept store Colette. Before it closed, Colette used to be the place to go when you were in Paris. They had their Colette shade of blue and we did a couple of Italian cashmere sweaters in that colour which sold really well. At the time, it was the best store to be placed in in the world.”

settings.grid-content:
Anna: “Our collaborations are all about creating happiness through nostalgia. Our first one – with Miffy – just resonated. A friend and I had always loved Miffy, and she would bring me back bits from trips to Japan. As you get older it’s always nice to feel young and reminisce about something you loved as a kid.”

Rachael: “We’ve also created collections with Moomins, Hello Kitty and Peanuts. Our next collaboration is with a brand that’s quintessentially English and very much part of my childhood...”

settings.title: 7. New HQ
settings.text: Rachael: “We moved to King’s Cross in 2018, leaving our office in Marylebone because we’d grown out of it. We were also ready to have a place we could put our Chinti mark on. Anna and I have gone from being literally in broom cupboards, where people would let us work until they kicked us out. It feels like Chinti is having a moment and so is the area so it’s nice to have that buzz all around us – and lots more space!”

settings.grid-content: Anna: “Our collaboration with Women for Women International came about because I was introduced to Arizona Muse. She had just started working with the charity and so we decided to work on a project together, creating a range of sweaters and donating the profits to this important cause. Giving back is a very small part of what a business should be doing, it’s the least we can do. Fashion can be a bit fickle so it’s nice to ground the business and make a bit of a difference at the same time as making lovely clothes.”

Anna: “Offering ready-to-wear as well as knitwear and jersey just felt like a natural progression because we were being asked for full looks and sometimes, depending on where you live, head-to-toe knit can be a little bit tricky. The idea was to keep the aesthetic relaxed and easy, creating pieces you could dress up or down for different situations. The thing we always want is to make our customers feel happy.”

Rachael: “We’re so much about print and colour and being able to offer a full look gives more impact. In some ways it’s easier to work with wovens than with knitwear because of the technicalities of translating a pattern onto a sweater. I wear Chinti every day, and it’s not just because I have to – I love wearing the product. I feel really proud when I wear what we’ve made.”

settings.title: 10. Putting down roots
settings.text:
Rachael: “We’ve just opened our first permanent store in Notting Hill’s Westbourne Grove in line with our 10th anniversary. It’s where we opened our first pop-up store last year, so it feels a bit like coming home. Regardless of whether you buy anything, you’re going to feel happier coming out of that store than you did when you first went in. It’s not just about purchasing things, it’s about having the full experience through the clothes, the colours and the lovely people who work with us.

Anna: “We’ll also continue to open pop-up stores like the one we currently have in St. John’s Wood; they offer a great opportunity for us to meet new customers and get to know their likes and dislikes.”
